data.title: Insider trades: IBM, Boeing, Coca-Cola among notable names
data.description:
This week insider transactions were seen across major companies like Boeing (BA), Coca-Cola (KO) and Palantir (PLTR). The following transactions occurred between February 23 and February 27.

  • Palantir (PLTR) saw several insider sales this week at the same price point of $133.72 per share. Chief Financial Officer  David Glazer sold 17,438 shares for a total value of $2.33M, leaving him with 392,370 shares post-transaction. Meanwhile, Chief Revenue Officer Ryan Taylor sold 19,988 shares for proceeds of $2.67M, retaining 219,421 shares.
  • At Coca-Cola (KO), Executive Vice President Monica Douglas disposed of 20,000 shares at $80.16 per share for $1.60M. She retains 64,644 shares.
  • Boeing (BA) recorded a smaller transaction, with EVP and Chief HR Officer  Uma Amuluru selling 1,503 shares at $233.79 per share for $351,484, leaving her with 19,015 shares.
  • Many transactions were also reported at Walmart (WMT). Latriece Watkins sold 10,000 shares at $121.46 per share for $1.21M, while Christopher Nicholas sold 34,082 shares at $122 per share, amounting to $4.16M. Their respective post-sale holdings stood at 109,958 and 533,466 shares.
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) saw Sr. EVP and General Counsel Ellen Patterson sell 60,000 shares at $87.40 per share, realizing $5,244,000 in proceeds and retaining 170,787 shares.
  • IBM (IBM) recorded two insider purchases by directors. Michelle Howard acquired 50 shares at $237.83 per share for $11,891, increasing her holdings to 194 shares, while Michael Miebach bought 434 shares at $233.33 per share, totaling $101,264, and now holds 434 shares.
  • Uber’s (UBER) Chief Financial Officer Balaji Krishnamurthy purchased 22,453 shares at an average price of $71.25 per share, investing about $1.60M, with total holdings rising to 28,742 shares.
  • IonQ (IONQ) also saw buying activity, with director William Teuber acquiring 3,000 shares at $38.38 per share for $115,155, bringing his total holdings to 9,413 shares.

data.title: Franklin Street Properties stock jumps on refinancing deal, continuing strategic review
data.description:
Franklin Street Properties (FSP) stock jumped 6.7% on Friday after the office properties REIT said it closed on a $320M secured credit facility to refinance near-term debt and is continuing its review of strategic alternatives.

With the close on the new credit facility, the REIT repaid in full the outstanding $248.9M aggregate principal amount of debt in an initial drawdown of $258.5M under the new facility, net of original issue discount of $16.5M. The new facility includes up to $45M of delayed draw term loans, which will be used to fund tenant improvements, leasing commissions, building improvements, and other uses approved by the lender, the company said. The refinancing brings in TPG (TPG) as a strategic lending partner.

"We believe that having successfully addressed our near-term debt maturities has reduced a significant source of near-term uncertainty and avoided having to make forced or suboptimal decisions, enabling us to focus on executing property-level initiatives in what continues to be an uneven office market environment," said Franklin Street Properties (FSP) Chairman and CEO George J. Carter. Furthermore, the company's board is committed to "continuing to explore ways to maximize shareholder value."

Key terms of the $320M facility include:

  • Original stated maturity of Feb. 26, 2029.
  • Initial coupon rate of 9.0%.
  • Exit fee of 4.0% of the funded amount of the loans due upon repayment.
  • A potential extension of up to one year at the option of the company, subject to certain conditions.
  • Collateral consisting of a first priority lien on substantially all assets of the company.

"After considering a number of different potential strategic alternatives in consultation with our professional advisors, we concluded that refinancing our outstanding indebtedness was the best alternative available to us at this time," Carter said.

data.title: Big Arch, big deal: McDonald's unveils its biggest hamburger ever in the U.S.
data.description:
McDonald's plans to launch its Big Arch Burger in the U.S. on March 3 as a highly anticipated limited-time offering. The menu item has already been introduced in several international markets, including the U.K. and Ireland, where it was elevated to the permanent menu after seeing strong sales.

The fast-food chain describes the Big Arch as two juicy quarter-pound 100% beef patties, layered with three slices of melty white cheddar cheese, and then topped with both crispy and slivered onions, zesty pickles, and crisp lettuce. The burger also features the tangy Big Arch sauce, which has a balance of mustard, pickle, and sweet tomato flavors. The 1020-calorie ensemble is served on a toasted sesame and poppy seed bun.

 

 

McDonald's (MCD) is framing the Big Arch as its biggest and "most McDonald’s" burger ever, aimed at guests wanting a heartier, higher-quality beef option without leaving the brand’s familiar flavor profile. Top management has tied the launch to McDonald’s (MCD) broader “Best Burger” initiative, which focuses on hotter, juicier burgers and upgraded buns as a way to drive traffic and check growth in the core burger category.

TD Cowen analyst Andrew Charles tested the Big Arches sandwich at a McDonald's (MCD) location in Toronto. He said the firm's view is that the sandwich does not fail on McDonald's (MCD) intention to deliver a larger burger to hungrier consumers. "We were most impressed by the Big Arch sauce that tasted of Dijon mustard with a mayonnaise consistency that offered a hint of garlic, as well as the poppy & sesame seed bun that invoked the taste, though not the texture, of an everything bagel."

The McDonald's hamburger move could impact chains such as Wendy's (WEN), Taco Bell (YUM), Jack in the Box (JACK), Sonic, Whataburger, Culver's, Five Guys, Freddy’s Frozen Custard & Steakburgers, Hardee's, Carl's Jr., Checkers/Rally's, In-N-Out, Habit Burger (YUM), Smashburger, White Castle, Dairy Queen, and Shake Shack (SHAK) to varying degrees. Coinciding with the Big Arch launch, Burger King's (QSR) iconic Whopper hamburger menu item is getting its first major upgrade in nearly a decade, although the chain pledged not to change  what fans love about the sandwich.

data.title: RSM’s Brusuelas says oil price hike could be temporary despite Iran strikes
data.description:
A potential rise in crude oil prices in response to American and Israeli attacks on Iran could be temporary, and prices could quickly return to pre-conflict levels, Joseph Brusuelas, RSM US chief economist, said on Saturday.

His remarks came after the U.S. and Israel launched a barrage of strikes against Iran on Saturday, triggering retaliatory attacks from the Iranian regime and risking a wider conflict in the oil-rich region.

Crude oil futures closed higher on Friday before hostilities began: front-month Nymex crude (CO1:COM) and front-month Brent crude (CO1:COM) for April delivery added 2.8% and 2.9%, respectively, while U.S. natural gas futures (NG1:COM) gained 1.1%.

In a post on X on Saturday, Brusuelas noted that crude oil prices had jumped 23% from Dec. 16 to Feb. 26 in the run-up to the onset of hostilities.

He pointed out that during 12 days of American-Israeli attacks on Iran last year, the U.S. witnessed a 15% and 3% rise in oil prices and domestic gasoline prices, respectively, “all of which quickly declined back to pre-conflict levels as hostilities ended.”

“While oil markets continue to closely watch and react to potential tensions in the Middle East, history has shown that the price increases are temporary and quickly revert back to near pre-conflict levels,” Brusuelas wrote.

data.title: Greg Abel stresses Berkshire Hathaway's prudent approach to its businesses in annual letter
data.description:
Throughout his first annual letter to shareholders, Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) (BRK.A) CEO Greg Abel reinforced the company's long-standing culture of making investment decisions wisely. Examples include reining back growth in insurance underwriting to maintain profit margins and refraining from expanding its utilities business to meet AI demand if it's not going to provide the appropriate payoff to shareholders. He also highlighted the need to improve operating margins at its BNSF rail operations. Here are the main takeaways in Abel's discussion of the company's businesses.

Insurance

Geico: The company's rate increases from late 2022 through 2024 have restored margins but have led to lower retention, Abel pointed out. "Restoring retention while maintaining underwriting discipline will take time," he said. The division is also investing in technology to improve efficiency and service while keeping its position as the industry's low-cost provider, he added.

Other primary property & casualty business: Additional capital entering the market has led to lower pricing or decelerating rate increases in some important lines. "We have always prioritized underwriting discipline over volume, and as pricing became less attractive, our premium growth plateaued," Abel said. Those headwinds are expected to continue in 2026 "and potentially beyond."

Berkshire Hathaway's (BRK.B) reinsurance operations are expected to write less reinsurance premium, primarily due to similar headwinds as the primary P&C business. Increased capital flowing into the market, along with a more benign reinsured catastrophe loss burden in 2025, has led to significant price declines in property reinsurance, he said. 

The company's insurance business will remain patient because of Berkshire's structural strengths, he added. The company's insurance float — the capital it holds to pay future losses and is invested for Berkshire's benefit — was at $176B at the end of 2025, up from $171B at the end of 2024.

Other operating businesses

BNSF: The rail division is focusing on improving its operating margin. In 2025, it widened to 34.5% from 32.0% in 2024 and is modestly above its five-year average. Each one percentage point improvement in operating margin equals ~$230M of incremental operating cash flow to its owners. "More progress is needed to translate operational improvements into stronger financial results," Abel said in the letter. "The team recognizes the significance of this opportunity, and we will be disappointed if we do not deliver a substantial improvement over the next few years."

Berkshire Hathaway Energy ((BHE)): The company prides itself on offering value to customers in the markets it serves, averaging 24% below the national retail electric rate level. Abel points out that infrastructure built for hyperscalers and data centers, alluding to burgeoning energy demand for AI, must be paid for by customers and reflects risk to step-changes in long-term demand. But, like Berkshire's other businesses, BHE won't focus on growth for growth's sake alone. "BHE will pursue this incremental growth and invest our shareholders’ capital only when those risks and rewards are appropriately balanced," Abel wrote.

He also said BHE is working on programs to mitigate wildfire risk and is taking responsibility when warranted. "When a BHE utility is responsible for a wildfire, it has acknowledged that responsibility, including PacifiCorp’s settlements related primarily to the 2020 Labor Day fires," he said. At the same time, it won't allow the company to be used as “deep pockets” to pay for damage that it didn't cause. "Where responsibility does not exist, it ((BHE)) will continue to seek judicial relief," Abel said.

Equity portfolio

Some 65% of Berkshire's equity portfolio is in five companies —  Apple (AAPL), American Express (AXP), Coca-Cola (KO),  Bank of America (BAC), and Chevron (CVX) — down from 71% in 2024. "This concentrated approach will continue, with limited activity in these holdings, though we may significantly adjust a holding if we see fundamental changes in its long-term economic prospects," Abel wrote. Its criteria for its investments in Japan are comparable to its major U.S. holdings "in importance and long-term value creation opportunity." 

Together, those positions at year-end totaled $194B in market value, or almost two-thirds of its $297.8B equity securities portfolio, providing combined dividends of $2.5B and yielding 10% on their original cost basis of $24.5B, Abel pointed out.

Abel also called out Berkshire's investment in Kraft Heinz (KHC) as disappointing. "Even after considering the preferred equity component in our original Heinz investment, our return has been well short of adequate," he wrote.

Responsibility for the equity portfolio's performance ultimately lies with Abel. But he noted that Ted Wechsler manages ~6% of Berkshire's investments, including a portion of the portfolio formerly managed by Todd Combs. "Ted’s impact extends beyond these investments, as he continues to play a broader role in assessing significant opportunities, providing valuable input on our businesses, and supporting Berkshire in various other ways," Abel wrote.

data.title: Notable analyst calls this week: Alphabet, Comcast and IBM among top picks
data.description:
The S&P 500 (SP500) closed in the red on Friday, after the week saw earnings reports from tech giants including Nvidia and Dell.

For the week, Nasdaq (COMP:IND) rose 1%, while Dow (DJI) gained 1.4%, respectively. Wall Street had a slew of upgrades and downgrades from analysts. Here are some of the major calls for the week:

Wells Fargo gives bullish rating to Alphabet

Wells Fargo upgraded tech giant Alphabet (GOOG) (GOOGL) to Overweight from Equal weight, citing its industry-leading capacity position to support internal efforts and monetization capabilities.

The brokerage believes the company has all the pieces necessary, namely customer data, distribution, and compute capacity, to be an AI winner.

GOOGL's PT was raised to $387 from $354 and said it expects Google's Gemini consumer subscription revenue business to exit 2027 at $12B ARR from $4B exiting 2025.

BNP downgrades Comcast, Cable One on fiber headwinds

BNP Paribas downgraded cable TV names Comcast (CMCSA) and Cable One (CABO) to Underperform from Neutral, as fiber expansion erodes the sector's market share.

The research firm said U.S. cable stocks collapsed due to expanding fiber and fixed wireless footprints, which "sapped the robust subscriber and ARPU growth that fueled their earlier outperformance."

CMCSA's price target was cut by $1 to $27. The research firm said Comcast is most exposed to fiber headwinds, and they view broadband revenue estimates as “too optimistic” for the second half of 2026. Similarly, CABO's PT was slashed by $45 to $80.

IBM upgraded on balanced risk/reward

UBS upgraded IBM (IBM) to Neutral from Sell, noting that the risk/reward going forward is more balanced.

"While we expect pushback on our rating pivot given the risk from Al across the software landscape and market concern that translating legacy COBOL using Al will hurt IBM infra, the competitive risk to IBM's Z vertically integrated platform is largely reflected in the shares with the stock trading at a 7% FCF yield. Therefore, while we continue to expect flattish 'Infra’ growth, we do not expect mainframe disintermediation over the next several years given strong customer stickiness, customer data sovereignty and complex vertically integrated stack that provides quantum-safe encryption," UBS said.

The firm has a $236 price target on the stock.

First Solar downgraded after weak outlook

Baird Research downgraded First Solar (FSLR) to Neutral from Outperform with a $205 price target, cut from $264, citing "several question marks in forward outlook" as management's post-earnings comments left the firm "incrementally negative even vs. our lowered expectations into the print."

First Solar (FSLR) continues to have a strong backlog position but remains hesitant with booking new business given outstanding variables with Section 232, clarity on FEOC, and global tariffs, among others, Baird analyst Ben Kallo wrote.

RBC Capital Markets has initiated coverage of AbbVie (ABBV) at Outperform saying the company has underperformed based on unfounded concerns and will benefit from growing Skyrizi and Rinvoq sales. The bank has a $260 price target on the stock.

data.title: Amex, Wells Fargo in top losers; Circle Internet, PayPal among gainers - week's financials wrap
data.description:
Wall Street's major indexes closed the last week of February on a disappointing note, while monthly returns also turned negative.

The benchmark S&P 500 index closed the last week of February 0.44% lower than the prior week and 0.87% lower compared to January at 6,878.84.

The markets saw a selloff on Monday as renewed uncertainty gripped markets following President Donald Trump's recent tariff announcement. Additionally, AI disruption fears continued to linger as software stocks dropped.

And while markets rebounded from the Monday selloff, large tech earnings and a hotter-than-expected wholesale inflation report marred sentiments.

Investor unease around the likelihood of an AI bubble is said to have impacted the megacap technology stocks.

Financials were also on the losing side. State Street Financial Sel Sec SPDR ETF (XLF) logged a loss of 2.02% on a weekly basis to close at $51.43.

Among the megacap stocks, American Express (AXP) led the pack. The stock pulled back by 10.77% to $308.90 amid a research report on Sunday, which revived fears that stablecoin-based technology will obviate the need for traditional card networks.

On Monday, Citrini Research released a hypothetical scenario on the disruption that agentic AI and stablecoins might cause in the enterprise software and payment sphere.

Wells Fargo (WFC), said to be among the Wall Street lenders exposed to the failed UK mortgage finance firm - Market Financial Solutions, was the next on the list.

The stock retreated 8.17% from the prior week to close at $81.45.

On the flip side, HSBC Holdings (HSBC) stood out as a clear winner in the category. The stock added 5.68% to end the week at $93.16.

Sentiments were lifted after the London-headquartered lender posted a higher Q4 revenue, a dividend hike, and new financial targets for 2026, 2027, and 2028.

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) (BRK.B) was also gaining in the run-up to the release of its Q4 results. BRK.A was up 1.41% week-over-week to $757K, while BRK.B increased 1.35% to $504.95.

Read about BRK's Q4 earnings here - Berkshire Hathaway Q4 operating earnings -30% Y/Y, cash pile hits $373.3B.

Nu Holdings (NU) (-14.55% W/W to $14.98) was the top decliner among largecap stocks. 

The São Paulo-based digital banking platform reported record Q4 revenue that exceeded Wall Street estimates, but saw a decrease in its efficiency ratio.

Meanwhile, Circle Internet Group (CRCL) (+32.40% W/W to $83.44) was the top weekly gainer.

The company behind the USDC stablecoin delivered Q4 earnings and revenue that topped consensus estimates as USDC in circulation at the end of the quarter climbed 72% from a year ago.

PayPal (PYPL) followed with a 10.95% weekly advance to close at $46.21.

The payments stock soared after a report that Stripe is considering an acquisition of all or parts of the company. However, another report said the company isn't in talks to sell itself to Stripe or anyone else.

The recent stock slump is said to have sparked the interest of some potential acquirers.

Read what analysts have to say here.

For the midcap stocks, Baldwin Insurance Group (BWIN) (+40.53% W/W to $23.23) and Sezzle (SEZL) (+16.25% W/W to $72.95) were among the significant gainers. Both companies posted Q4 earnings that exceeded the Street consensus.

SLM (SLM), having declined 17.08% from last week to close at $18.74, led the losers in the category

Jefferies Financial Group (JEF) followed. The stock slumped 16.87% to $44.40 after the company was sued by investors in one of its funds over losses related to its holdings in First Brands Group.

Additionally, Jefferies is said to have had an exposure of ~£100M to the failed UK firm MFS.

FS KKR Capital (FSK) (-16.73% to $10.80) and Banco Macro (BMA) (-16.35% W/W to $77.18). The two posted Q4 results this week, with FSK slashing dividend by ~30%.

In the smallcap category, PRA Group (PRAA), Goosehead Insurance (GSHD), and Walker & Dunlop (WD) were among the notable movers.

data.title: Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting to add some new faces to the dais
data.description:
With Greg Abel set to lead his first Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) (BRK.B) annual meeting on May 2, 2026, he'll have more company on stage with him, expanding some from the decades of annual meetings where Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger primarily fielded shareholders' questions.

The shift in format underscores that, under Abel's leadership, the focus at the annual meeting will be less on the personality of its CEO and more on the company's operations, bringing new faces to the dais.

The 2026 meeting will include a CEO's update on the company and two Q&A sessions — one with Abel and Ajit Jain, who heads Berkshire's insurance operations, and a second with Katie Farmer, who heads its BNSF rail division, and Adam Johnson, who leads NetJets, as well as its consumer products, service, and retailing operations.

"In that way, we will be able to cover Berkshire’s insurance and non-insurance operations," Abel wrote in his annual letter to shareholders. "While each session has a natural focus based on who is on stage with me, shareholders may ask me any question at any time."

data.title: Berkshire operating earnings drop amid insurance headwinds
data.description:
Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A)(BRK.B) recorded a surge in its cash pile with its Q4 2025 results on Saturday, even as the conglomerate under Warren Buffett’s last quarter as CEO witnessed a sharp decline in its operating earnings amid headwinds in its insurance businesses.

The company posted $10.2B as its operating earnings for the quarter, with a ~30% YoY drop, as its insurance-underwriting segment generated $1.6B in operating earnings with over a 54% YoY decline, and its insurance-investment income fell ~25% YoY to $3.1B.

Meanwhile, its railroad business, BNSF, added $1.3B with a ~5% YoY rise, and manufacturing, service, and retailing generated $3.4B with a ~3% YoY growth.

For the full year, the Omaha, Nebraska-based firm added $44.5B in operating earnings with a ~6% YoY decline compared to the $37.5B the company has averaged over the past five years.

Overall, full-year net earnings attributable to its shareholders fell 25% YoY to $66.7B from $89.0B in 2024. The company didn’t implement any stock purchases during the year even as its cash pile rose nearly 12% YoY to $373.3B as of Dec. 31.

Berkshire’s (BRK.A) insurance businesses were among notable underperformers in 2025, adding a combined $19.8B in operating earnings with a ~13% YoY fall, while its BNSF and Energy segments outperformed.

CEO Greg Abel, in his first annual letter to shareholders, noted that after implementing changes to pricing and policy terms for years, the company witnessed a deceleration or reversal of trends in its insurance businesses, especially in the second half of 2025. “This likely means we will write less property and casualty business for a period of time,” he added.

Meanwhile, BNSF, which runs one of the largest railroad systems in North America, generated $5.5B in operating earnings in 2025 with ~9% YoY growth, while Energy added $4.0B with ~7% YoY growth.

Berkshire’s (BRK.A) investment gains more than doubled to $13.5B during the quarter, thanks to $9.6B in unrealized gains in its equity investment holdings, while full-year investment gains fell ~26% YoY to $30.7B.

data.title: Berkshire Hathaway's Abel commits to uphold unique culture Buffett, Munger built
data.description:
New Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B), (BRK.A) CEO Greg Abel assured the company's shareholders on Saturday that he will continue Warren Buffett's legacy of responsibly handling  its investors' capital.

"Your capital is commingled with ours, but it does not belong to us," Abel wrote in his first annual letter to shareholders. "Our role is stewardship. That stewardship has shaped a culture and reinforced a set of values that are not the result of our success, but the reason for it."

Likewise, in a letter to employees, he promised that "Berkshire’s culture and values remain unchanged and will continue into perpetuity." That letter also committed to "strengthening the great legacy built by Warren Buffett and his business partner Charlie Munger, ensuring it endures through our commitment to excellence."

Core to the company's values are its decentralized model, integrity, financial strength, capital discipline, risk management, and operational excellence, he said.

In his discussion of Berkshire's (BRK.B) operations in 2025, he noted that its insurance business will likely write less property and casualty business "for a period of time." He explained that after several years of pricing and policy adjustments, 2025 started to show a deceleration or reversal of trends, especially in the second half of the year.

Developing… Check back for updates.
